bestBHT.bht: To know what is good and not do it is sin. It is not simply about neglecting one's duties, but actively choosing evil over good when the right path is clear. Having knowledge of what is right but not putting it into practice is a great and presumptuous sin. Feelings and knowledge are useless if not embodied in actions. This sin of omission is just as serious as committing an actual sin. Therefore, it is important to not only know what is right, but to actively do good deeds.

Henry Alford: This conclusion is most naturally understood to refer to the universal notoriety of the shortness of human life, and to apply only to the subject just treated.
To him who knoweth to do good, and doeth it not, it is sin to him.
It is not sins of omission that men are here convicted of, as so often mistakenly supposed: but the doing evil, as in the case of the speech above supposed, where good is easy and obvious.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Knowledge without practice is imputed to a man as great and presumptuous sin.
Nothing more injures the soul than wasted impressions.
Feelings exhaust themselves and evaporate, if not embodied in practice.
Albert Barnes: He who knows what sort of views he should take in regard to the future, and how he should form his plans in view of the uncertainty of life, and still does not do it...is guilty of sin against God."
If he understands what his duty is; if he has the means of doing good to others...he is under obligations to do it: and if...he does not do it, he is guilty of sin before God.

No man can be released from the obligation to do good in this world to the extent of his ability; no one should desire to be...if a man does not do this when he has the means, he sins against his own soul, against humanity, and against his Maker.
Philip Schaff: Therefore: not a mere general inference drawn from what St. James has said in the previous part of his Epistle, but a particular inference drawn from this spirit of vain boasting.
The omission of good is undoubtedly a sin, as well as the commission of evil. We have here the statement of an important principle, which is susceptible of endless applications.
You know the right and do the wrong, and therefore are convicted of sin.
Archibald T. Robertson: Unused knowledge of one's duty is sin, the sin of omission."
And to one not doing it.
John Gill: A Gnostic, or one that knows the will of God, in the several branches of it, revealed in his word, and doth it not, to him it is sin: it is a greater sin; it is an aggravated one.
It is criminal in him that is ignorant of what is good, and does that which is evil, nor shall he escape punishment.
The omission of a known duty, as well as the commission of a known sin, is criminal.
John Wesley: To him that knoweth to do good and doeth it not...That knows what is right, and does not practise it."
This knowledge does not prevent, but increase, his condemnation.
